Photo: Photo By Steve Bennett / Photo By Steve Bennett Image 16 of 16 Incarnate Word’s Fine Arts Complex state-of-the-art 1 / 16 Back to Gallery The University of the Incarnate Word has opened its new $15-million, 73,000-square-foot Fine Arts Complex, which features new facilities for visual arts and music studies, as well as an acoustically advanced concert hall and a large public sculpture.
Here are some of the complex’s features.
Music:
The 1928 auditorium was given a complete makeover and features 494 seats, as well as an e-coustic speaker system so the hall can be “tuned” for different types of music, from jazz bands to choral ensembles.
100-seat recital hall
choir and band rehearsal halls
music therapy suite
piano lab
recording studio with an SSL sound mixing board
iMac lab for music instruction
seven teaching studios for private lessons
18 Wenger modular practice rooms
sheet music library
Art:
three art galleries: the Kelso Gallery, Semmes Gallery and a student exhibition space
designated studios for painting, printmaking and photography
two darkrooms for photography
computer lab for digital photography
In addition, the building facade features a 40-foot-by-20-foot aluminum sculptural mural titled “ The Source of Life” by local sculptor Cakky Brawley .
